tout.altText: Ryan Leslie: Ryan Leslie
tout.title: Ryan Leslie: Ryan Leslie.png

title: Ryan Leslie
dek: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Ryan Leslie’s breezy and lovestruck 2009 solo debut, a set of virtuoso R&B productions that emerged in a new era of online music culture.
seoDescription: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Ryan Leslie’s breezy and lovestruck 2009 solo debut, a set of virtuoso R&B productions that emerged in a new era of online music culture.
promoDescription: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Ryan Leslie’s breezy and lovestruck 2009 solo debut, a set of virtuoso R&B productions that emerged in a new era of online music culture.
socialDescription: Read Clover Hope’s review of the album.

tout.altText: Warren Zevon: Warren Zevon
tout.title: Warren Zevon: Warren Zevon

title: Warren Zevon
dek: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Warren Zevon’s 1976 breakthrough, an unforgettable collection of rock songs as short stories set in a seedy, mythological American West.
seoDescription: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Warren Zevon’s 1976 breakthrough, an unforgettable collection of rock songs as short stories set in a seedy, mythological American West.
promoDescription: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Warren Zevon’s 1976 breakthrough, an unforgettable collection of rock songs as short stories set in a seedy, mythological American West.
socialDescription: Read Andy Cush’s review of the album.
